title: Age of Mythology Extended Edition
review:
Update: Crashing has finally been fixed but took WAY to long.


I have to say that I was very happy when this came out I am an original player and was very excited when I was able to play again.  The truth is that enough is enough.   They are coming out with new material and the game crashes ever other game.  I love this game and will gladly change this to a yes once they fix this.  However, the game litterally crashes or "dysynics" everyother game.  This happens to everybody so nobody try and say its just me play 10 games and then tell me it does not.  The developers have ruined a classic game and I am deeply saddened that they were the ones who were given the rights to this.  This is my favorite PC game and I hate to give it a no rating.  PLEASE fix this.

title: Age of Mythology Extended Edition
review:
Edit: Whoops! Wrong text. Updated.

This is one of my favourite games. I've played it for years and recently bought it here on sale just so I could play with friends. I would say it starts off really easy but can get quite difficult in bigger games. There are some aspects of micro-managing armies which are missing but which would be super useful, but I find getting good at the early game / startup is your best bet for success and sort of overrides any shortcomings of the late game. I love the cartoony graphics relative to other RTS games, and the god powers add an extra layer of fun and frustration. Excellent for playing with mates.

title: Age of Mythology Extended Edition
review: I have a lot of nostalgia for this game and upon replaying it again, it seems to have held up the test of time. This is a fairly basic strategy game but what I love about it is that it features creatures and heroes from Greek, Egyptian and Norse mythology. The story is not too bad, though the writing is fairly basic, it still does provide some interesting avenues such as connecting the mythologies of very different cultures. I think fans of strategy games would like this game and appreciate it even more if you are even slightly interested in Ancient mythology.

title: Age of Mythology Extended Edition
review:
I played the main campaign as a teen, and replaying it was a great hit of nostalgia. I did actually enjoy the extension campaigns too, although the Ancient China one got ridiculous a couple of levels in, and seemed like a mediocre mod at best.

The follow-on '10 years later' Atlantis campaign did impress me, however - but that may be because I played it after the China one, so my expectations were low. There was a world of difference though, and I was very pleasantly surprised to hear the original voice actors participate.

All-in-all, if you're a fan of this genre and don't mind the dated graphics, this is a good game - up there with the classics.

title: Age of Mythology Extended Edition
review:
This game is my childhood. I can recall the amount of HOURS I spent on the editor and replaying the main campaigns (Fall Of The Trident and The New Atlantis) because I love the characters and the story so much! I bought this on sale just for fun and ended up reliving one of the best early video game experiences of my life.
That said, I was expecting more of the Chinese expansion... the gods and units are cool, but the campaign is incredibly lazy in both plot and map design. It definitely doesn't have the same quality as the originals.
So I unistall the game now with a smile on my face, but also with a bittersweet feeling caused by high expectations that were not met on a *fairly recently* released expansion. I wonder what's the story behind that. However I may come back to it to spend some much needed time in the editor.

-TLDR: Buy it to replay the original campaigns, definitely. I felt they were worth replaying, but I wouldn't have played the chinese expansion if I had known how bad it is beforehand.

title: Age of Mythology Extended Edition
review: Old but great real-time strategy game. Loved playing as a kid, and still love it today. would greatly recommend to those who like mythology. The game has loads of room for different strategies and play styles. Extremely high skill ceiling that will reward skill and experience. Endless possibilities with the editor mode. Multiple entertaining story modes. Overall good game.

title: Age of Mythology Extended Edition
review:
Used to be an amazing game, back when it came out. Then they took this old, but amazing game and replaced the water and put it on steam for like 40‚Ç¨. I liked the old water better. It fit the game and wasnt buggy as hell. Now, the game wont even start properly. Theres no background, like there used to be. There used to be a scenario in the background, but now it doesnt load. The map editor needs a lot of improvements as well. No way near the qualities of the Warcraft 3 map editor. There is a ton of bugs and glitches and the performance is bad. They broke the saving system, now its working again. There is also still a bug present that allows you to build a Wonder in one of the campaign missions, even though youre not supposed to be able to do that. 

From what I have read, the "dev team" behind this "update" is just a bunch of modders that asked Microsoft for permission to work on the game. Could have just put it on steam for like 15‚Ç¨ in the original form with bugfixes and support. Instead, they are ruining one of my favourite games and Im paying money for it...

PS: The background failing to load or the map loading as black screen is related to profiles. Create a new one.

title: Age of Mythology Extended Edition
review:
"So you're telling me I can fit 20 elephant soldiers in that small transport ship but I can't fit my Titan in there?"

What happens if you get Age of Empires but inject some funny monsters and deities in the mix? You get this game!

All the funny shenanigans you could do in Age of Empires are expanded and extended almost ten-fold with the magical wonders of Age of Mythology.

Get some friends and play! They don't really make this kind of classic RTS anymore, to be honest. This is a golden opportunity to relive that golden--nah scratch that--that Mythic Age of RTS gaming! And with your friends, no less!

title: Age of Mythology Extended Edition
review:
Age of Mythology: Extended Edition is a good example of a poorly made cash grab.
The Extended tag probably means the new bugs Skybox Labs managed to produce, that didn't exist in the original.

The AI pathfinding is messed up. Units often phase/clip through the walls and villagers often get stuck in larger buildings (Temple, Wonder, Titan Gate) they finished building.

The changes to the graphics are highly questionable. The new textures are washed out and blurry, so it's highly recommended to revert them to something that looks closer to the original (EG: Epic textures mod). Otherwise you will have a hard time finding your units, as they blend into the environment too well. 

Last but not least the netcode. Oh, boy! If you thought Age of Empires 2 HD's netcode was bad, then you have no idea what this game has in store for you. The online matches are insane lagfests, often freezing up for  seconds, rendering the game unplayable.

Bottom line is that this version of the game is a mess. Skip it, you're not missing out much!

title: Age of Mythology Extended Edition
review:
Still an amazing game after all this time.

But and a big but here
It is not worth buying (at full price) due to the fact that the graphics look almost the same as when it was released in 2002 with little other improvements to the game play.  Though you don't really need to mess with near perfection but it would have been nice to see some modernization to the UI.

Additionally they released a new pantheon, the Chinese, but it is not worth getting at full price as well.  If they had included the Chinese in the base then it would be worth $30.

This game was a major part of my childhood and I cannot recommend it enough despite how they handled the Extended Edition.

title: Age of Mythology Extended Edition
review:
I've played this game a lot, and consider it to be one of the best strategy games out there. 

Having said that, the multiplayer aspect of this game is awful. This game isn't new to steam and yet the basic bugs haven't been fixed - games crashing as they load, games crashing after random amounts of time, large amounts of lag in most games and lobby's that you can't join for no clear reason. 

I really want to recommend this game as the game itself is brilliant, but the bugs really take the fun out of playing it. I'd say 7/10 games experience at least some problems with players lagging or the game crashing. The longer a game goes on the more likely it will experience some kind of problem. 

If this is fixed I would 100% recommend this game, and say it is worth every penny.

title: Age of Mythology Extended Edition
review: This game is amazing and while I don't love it like I love Age of Empires 2 and 3 I still consider Mythology a great addition to the series. Only thing that bothered me was the historical accuracy which a lot of you will find funny considering the mythical setting but hear me out. Greek mythology takes place way before events like Alexander the Great's conquest of the Persian Empire, The collapse of the Bronze Age, and Persia's multiple invasions of the Greek city states. Yet there is siege units in this game like siege towers, catapults, scorpions, and battering rams which the Greeks didn't even invent yet until Alexander's father King Phillip's rule in Macedonia. Also there are Cavalry units with men riding horses which is ridiculous because horses at this time hadn't developed into the strong and huge beasts we know them today. During days of the Hitties, Trojans, and ancient greeks in the Trojan War horses were more like Ponies and their backs wouldn't be able to support the weight of full grown men so that's another historical inaccuracy. There were no black people in Ancient Egypt they would have been resembled more to the Arabs, Persians, and brownish people at that time so just dumb blackwashing! I think that's all that bothered me about the historical accuracy. The mythical units however are a fantastic addition! Being able to summon armies of Hydras or Cyclops monsters to help and fight alongside your armies of men is so much fun! The singleplayer campaign is great! I recommend this game it is so beautiful the graphics and scenery hold up and this remaster does a fantastic job reminding people of it's beauty with new weather and graphical effects!

title: Age of Mythology Extended Edition
review:
I remember this game's original release back in the early 2000s and while the Steam version differs in some ways, it does give players the opportunity to continue playing this timeless classic. If you are considering buying this game for the first time or are a returning player wondering if it's worth it to buy the game again, here is a simple pro/con list to help with your decision.

Pros:

+Great campaigns (that's right, plural): the extended edition comes with a tutorial campaign, a 32 mission main story campaign, the Golden Gift prequel mini-campaign and the 13 mission Titan's expansion campaign. This totals over 50 levels if you include the tutorial and they are all well crafted.
+Good story: It clearly wont be as good as AAA titles that have the ability to create greater stories such as the Red Dead Redemption series, Elder Scrolls, Halo, or other top tier games, but it still has stunning moments as well as some twists and surprises to look forward to.
+Fantastic unit/building/terrain design: This is pretty straight forward as you can tell that the developers spent a good amount of time on the unique designs not only between the 4 civilizations, but to the individual buildings and units as well.
+Good soundtrack: The background music truly fits the time period and can be quite catchy at times.
+Replayability: With the different civilizations, main gods, and lesser gods to choose, there are many different playstyles to choose from that will offer plenty of paths to experience the game in different ways.
+Maps: There are dozens of maps set in every possible location both realistic and fictional and the multiplayer and custom games have many options for victory conditions as well as other settings.
+Myth units: The Myth units in the game add a lot of flavor to a genre that gravitates towards ordinary soldiers or uniform groups, especially since each creature is completely different in both design and usage.
+Strategy: As the name of genre would demand, this game has no end to the strategies and tactics that may be used.

Cons:

-Multiplayer: Since AoM was added to steam, it has suffered from very clear problems whether you host a custom game, or go right into the public matches. 
-Tale of The Dragon: The add-on dlc that the new developers created with the steam version is clearly not the same as the base game or the titans expansion. The other reviews for this game make it clear that it could have been handled better but luckily it comes as a separate purchase so you can avoid both the gameplay as well as the new (and lets be honest, inferior) main menu design.
-Graphics changes: For some unclear reason, the graphics options, as well as the settings menu, seems slightly more restrictive than the original. In fact, the units don't seem to stay high quality when exiting a cutscene like they did before (although it is possible that I am wrong in this case).

As a long time player of Age of Mythology, I can say that this is a worthy game of the money, especially if you have friends to play with.

When factoring everything in, I will give the game a 9/10 although I can see the more multiplayer focused players giving a slightly lower score.

title: Age of Mythology Extended Edition
review:
A game I played the heck out of as a kid, I grew up loving it and the fantasy and the lore it wove! 

Sure the RTS gameplay is a bit dated by today's standards, but its focus on the core rock paper scissors of traditional army build thrown in with the extra flair of mythological units just makes you FEEL like one of these civilizations of the mythical age! 

And lets not forget the story, OH MY GOD THE STORY!! It truly is an Epic worthy of the greats like Homer in spirit and imagination. It owns the cheese it's dripping with like a perfect 80's movie. You just can't help but smile and get sucked into the world. 

If there ever was a game in my heart I hoped got a sequel, this would be at the top of my list!
May the gods ever bless you with their Favour!

review:
Let me start off by saying that this is one of my favorite childhood games.
I was really excited to see it being added in the Steam library.
However, for this price, it is not worth buying!
The graphics are not remastered at all and you get the same results by tweaking the game files of the original 2002 game yourself.
The new Asian expansion is not a good reason for me to buy this game either.
The only thing this new Steam version has going for itself is the new Multiplayer support (versus the now defunct old servers).
In conclusion: Stick with your original CD from 2002 if you have it or buy this game on sale.

title: Age of Mythology Extended Edition
review:
Age of Mythology build on the highly playable Age of Empires series with a few modifications. The biggest change is that you get to play with myth units, titans, and heroes, and you also get god powers after advancing to each of the four ages. I also enjoyed the fact that you get to play five different cultures, and each culture has its own advantages and disadvantages. The campaigns are very fun to play, and are sometimes very challenging. The extended edition offers three or four extra campaigns, so you will be spending 40 hrs + in finishing them. 

Then there is the random map mode where you can customize the number of players you want to play against, the map size, the god powers, etc. I spent COUNTLESS hours trying to beat the computer on the hard and even the moderate difficulty settings. The AI is brilliant and the enemy will try to exploit every possible weakness in your civilization. 

The music is brilliant, a mixture of ancient and modern instruments. 

One drawback of the game is that the enemy can easily break through walls in most cases, and siege weapons can level buildings very quickly if they are not destroyed right away. Also, I don't like the fact that the AI will frequently try to kill your villagers if they try to gather resources outside the walls of your civilization. Quite a few of the improvements such as stronger walls are too expensive. 

Overall it is an extremely creative and immersing game that will give your endless twist and turns and hours and hours of play time. I would rate it 9.3/10

title: Age of Mythology Extended Edition
review:
Get it on sale.
I still love the game itself, it is and always will be a childhood classic for me, but this remake doesn't do much aside from make it easily playable on Steam and give it workshop support.
They neglected to modernize the hotkeys for the game, so playing can be exceedingly clunky when compared to other modern RTS experiences.
The night lighting on all but a few maps makes it hard to discern elements and units on the map. You can even see this in some of the screenshots on this store page, units are about as hard to see there as they are in game.
The improved water is hardly noticeable. Same with the shadows. Same with the specular maps. The improved lighting is noticeable but doesn't obscure that everything else looks like we're on a Windows Vista. You can put a ribbon on a dead frog, it's still a dead frog.
The antialiasing is nice I guess, I really needed my 40x40 texture quality and 6-poly models from the mid-2000s to be nice and smooth.
The view lock is stupidly constrained, no one would play like that, I have no idea why that's even on by default.
Literally couldn't care less about the trading cards, cloud saves, leagues, twitch, etc since the multiplayer scene is presumably dead. It doesn't help that the trading card art is ugly as sin. Why is Odin flashing me his nipple in a night-gown astride Sleipnir while casting magic missile? Why does Thor have a massive overbite with a beard that looks like a felt carpet? Why is Zeus a glowing eyes meme? What does any of this have to do with old pantheons? Do I care? No lol, just get rid of them, they're ugly.
Probably my biggest dig at this release is the almost objectively worse ui design and decisions. There's less variation in menu backgrounds from the original game. Some of them are deliberately hidden for the new DLC. The in-game hud ui looks uglier over-all (How you pull that off with a decades old game, idk) and is at times thematically inconsistent. Generally anything related to the ui they broke or made worse, instead of improving.
Thankfully much of the ui blunders are fixable with mods, but they really shouldn't have to be. I should want your new changes, not to cover them up.
The new art, namely the splash screen, game icon and other ui elements are laughably bad. I mean they got someone who knows how to draw, sure, but not someone who has any sense for design or composition. Why they didn't just retain much of the original art is beyond me.
They locked the larger map size behind a stupid DLC that has abysmal reviews with units that look like they were designed as part of a freshman level student project that got a C-.
And of course the AI is easily beaten unless you're playing against the Titan level which deliberately cheats in resources and isn't even close to being a proper analogue for challenging a competent, real player.
I haven't dipped into multiplayer and I won't be as I've seen enough in the reviews to expect either a dead scene or my first five games to result in disconnects.

Perhaps AOE2:DE has spoiled me, but there's a certain bare minimum that I expect with a re-release of a decades old game, and this doesn't meet it. I'd say buy it for the workshop content, but not at full price. I do hope Microsoft comes back to give this some love and just tidy up the mess.

title: Age of Mythology Extended Edition
review:
[h1]Follow our [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/36214917/]Curator Group for more reviews[/url][/h1]
Age of Mythology: Extended Edition is a moderately updated version of a classic RTS. The improvements are nice, but ultimately not too impactful.

The biggest change isn‚Äôt even really a part of the game, it‚Äôs the steam workshop integration. It gives access to a decently sized collection of maps, scenarios and mods. The community is surprisingly active given the game‚Äôs age and it helps round out the overall experience.

The RTS gameplay is largely unchanged from the original, so fans of Age of Mythology shouldn‚Äôt have any issue with this version. For newcomers, Age of Mythology‚Äôs defining feature is the Major and Minor Gods system. As you progress you pick gods to worship which unlock unique units, upgrades and god powers (spells). This adds a ton of variety as the same faction will have many different god combinations to try out that all play differently. It also adds a level of counter-play to the game, allowing factions that are normally bad against certain strategies to tailor their god choices around that weakness. The single player campaign is also pretty solid, although not particularly challenging. Overall, a great game that still holds up years later.

9/10

title: Age of Mythology Extended Edition
review:
I  love RTS and the "Age of" series is one of the best. Multiple resources, loads of buildings, varied missions, etc. Age of Mythology is quite similar to its older sibling Age of Empires II but has quite a few tricks up its sleeve the way it handles different ages. You get to chose the age which differs the units you get, the special powers you get and the perks you get. Some of the units completely change how you'll play the game (flying fire-breathing dinosaurs anyone?).

The first 5 levels I didn't like the game too much - combat felt messy and uncontrolled, a free for all where tactics went out of the window, but you slowly learn how the AI works, how to drag proper tactics back into things. Your units keep running through the gates instead of letting the guard towers do the work? Just build a wall covering the gate.  Or how about teasing  enemies to go after a fast unit whereas the slower ones pick them off one at a time as you run them around in circles. It's this that makes the game fun: figuring out all the mechanics so that the negatives no longer bother you as much.

There are some negatives though:
- terrible pathfinding causing enemies to refuse to move or even get stuck in scenery
- units don't make way for other units. Even in Command & Conquer, units would make way for other units trying to pass by. This game has no such thing. If units block a passage, no-one else will get through
- unit control is not as tactical as I'd like - there's no way to tell units to move back to their original position so when positioning units close to a gate, you constantly have to pull them back after each attack. Standing ground often  makes them stop attacking altogether.
- there are a LOT of units but I find quite a few have no real use in combat, being overshadowed by other better units. I never used the elephants for example because I felt they weren't worth it - slow, not that powerful and easily replaced by other units.

title: Age of Mythology Extended Edition
review: This game has single handedly changed the entire course of my entire life. From Greek mythology tales, to the Nordic ideologies of warrior culture and ethos. It reminds me that anyone could and can be a hero in every aspect of life. Pure motivation and valor courses through my veins when I play this game. This game is responsible for America's freedom. The home of the brave wouldn't be so homely without this game. I believe that this game creates heroes. I believe that this game creates homes. I personally met my wife of 6 years while in the pregame lobby on this game. We are happily married with one beautiful boy named Jett. Thank you Ensemble Studios for changing my life.

title: Age of Mythology Extended Edition
review: I had the CD-Rom of the base game for years until it stopped working. I found out through inquires on Reddit that it had a steam version and have been playing since, I've had the game for years now, I don't remember when I bought it exactly but at least more then 4 years or so. My CD-Rom did not have Titans or any of the extras, it was just the base game... At first I was very sad I'd never get to play again until I was pointed to this version. This is by far my favorite game for a strategy game, I will always come back to it. I don't play online, but I do play the other modes, I'm a bit stuck on the Norse part of the story but I'll get through it one day. I can make games last for me for hours on end, it just cheers me up after a point.. Stops my mind from thinking of whats going wrong in RL, just from how much you need to think on your feet. I've swapped my game mode to easy with more enemies to draw the game out even longer as the other two modes just go by to fast for me. I hope this game stays supported! <3 <3 :)

title: Age of Mythology Extended Edition
review: This is just like the old AoM but with updated graphics. I loved this game but this target acquisition is absolutely horrendous. I don't understand why combat units target, with extreme prejudice, non combat units. The developers must know this is happening. I'm not about to play a game to micro every single action these combat units do. The attack move order is just a move order and an army can be easily defeated by trying to kill a group of villagers rather than THE ENEMY ATTACKING THEM. It is of extreme irritation.

title: Age of Mythology Extended Edition
review:
This game is masterclass.  I played it at release and its still my favorite RTS of all time.

The story line is great featuring a lot of mission variety and unique heroes to meet and fight with along the way. Build armies of mythical creatures, human units, heroes and titans.  The unit selection is truly massive.

On top of that there's a crap load of fun god powers to use depending on what gods you have selected to worship as your civilization progresses through the ages.

Honestly I could go on forever about this game, its just fun and that's all the more reason you need to buy it.

10/10 from me

title: Age of Mythology Extended Edition
review:
This game was first released in 2002.  Yes, 18 years ago.

Not many games are still enjoyable both in game play and graphic after 18 years?

Its reasons to age so wonderfully are multi folded:

1) The extended edition push up the resolution to HD.  However, the character models are still polygon looking of low quality craft, as of the standard of 2002.

2) Fan mods further added stunning looking terrain tile sets to enhance the graphic, just grab them from workshop.  That solved the aged tile set problem.  Last problem is the look of the objects and characters.

3) Install the zoom out mod - this took advantage of modern computing power and also make all ugly polygon no longer noticeable because the zoom out act as anti-aliasing and all characters good looking now.  This complete the transformation from a 2002 crude looking game into a 2020 era game.

The above 3 factors made the game graphic look quite on par with modern release.  Incredible for a 18 years old game that was not remade.

Highly recommended.

review: As much as I love AoM, I can't recommend this version.  It's riddled with tons of gamebreaking bugs and glitches that make the game unplayable, and yet it hasn't seen a real update in years; plus the multiplayer and mod scene are dead.  Just wait for AoM DE to inevitably come out in a few years, and play the old version in the mean time

title: Age of Mythology Extended Edition
review: AoM takes everything you love about age of empires (it's similar to many in the RTS realm) and expands upon it by adding mythic units, sharper graphics, and offering variety in the form of the way each of the tribes gains their "favor" to build said mythic units. The extended edition includes more than what I had on the game and even the titans expansion in disc format from way back in the day and overall, if you are a fan of the genre, you probably won't be disappointed here. Satisfying single player and enjoyable multiplayer add up to a winner here.

title: Age of Mythology Extended Edition
review: More often than not, childhood video games age horrifically. This is not the case for AOM. This game still holds up nearly two decades after its release and is to date, one of the most solid RTS experiences I've had the pleasure of playing. This is also one of the few games I own that I actually occasionally replay in its entirety. 2.5 thumbs up, would recommend.
